tit.e: Kurodo no betto (Chief of the Chamberlain's Office)
Kurodo no betto (Chief of the Chamberlain's Office)
Kurodo no betto (Chief of the Chamberlain's Office)

sen.j: 蔵人別当（くろうどのべっとう）とは、令外官の役職で、蔵人所の長官にあたる。
sen.e: Kurodo no betto was a post of Ryoge no kan (class ouside of the Ritsuryo system), corresponding to Kami at Kurododokoro (Chief of the Chamberlain's Office).
Kurodo no betto was a post of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) that was equivalent to a Kami (chief) of the Kurododokoro (Chamberlain's Office).
Kurodo no betto was a post of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) that was equivalent to a Kami (chief) of the Kurododokoro (Chamberlain's Office).

sen.j: 組織上は蔵人頭以下を指揮する立場にあるが、所内の実務全般は蔵人頭が責任を負い、蔵人別当は対外的な代表者の地位にあり、実際の実務には携わらない名目的なものであった。
sen.e: Kurodo no Betto was in an organizational position to supervise all the staff including Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain). However, Kurodo no to was actually responsible for all the practical business of the Chamberlain's Office while Kurodo no betto was regarded as a public representative of the Chamberlain's Office, a nominal position not involved in practical business.

Although Kurodo no betto was in an organizational position to supervise the entire staff at the Kurododokoro, including the Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain), all of the general practical business at the Kurododokoro was the responsibility of the Kurodo no to and the Kurodo no betto was regarded only as a public representative and honorary position not involved in practical business.

One person was appointed to this post.
The post was limited to one person at a time.
The post was limited to one person at a time.

sen.j: 殿上人を束ねる役目なので「殿上の別当」とも言う。
sen.e: As the role of this post was to govern Tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace), it was also called "Tenjo no betto."
As the role of a Kurodo no betto was to supervise the Tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed inot the Imperial Palace), it was also referred to as "Tenjo no betto."

sen.cmt: クォーテーション、スペルを変えました。

sen.j: 詔勅を各省に伝達することが役目である。
sen.e: The official duty of this post was to deliver Shochoku (Imperial edict) to each ministry.
The official duty of this post was to deliver Shochoku (Imperial edict) to each ministry.
The official duty of this post was to deliver Shochoku (Imperial edict) to each ministry.

sen.j: なお、通常、大臣が兼職して二位の者が補任されるが、令外官であるため官位相当は無い。
sen.e: Normally, Minister held this post concurrently, and the Second-rank personnel were appointed to this post; however, since this was a post of Ryoge no kan, there was no official rank corresponding to this post.

Although a Daijin (cabinet minister) and Second-rank personnel were generally appointed to Kurodo no betto as a second post, because it was Ryoge no kan the post did not have a corresponding official rank.
sen.cmt: "held this post concurrently"→"appointed to Kurodo no betto as a second post"; fixed grammar

sen.j: 897年（寛平9年）、平安時代前期の公卿藤原時平が任じられたのが最初であるが、後に左大臣が兼任することとなる。
sen.e: In 897, Kugyo (the top court officials) FUJIWARA no Tokihira in the early Heian period was the first one to be appointed to this post; in later years, Sadaijin (Minister of the Left) held this post concurrently.

During the early Heian Period in 897, the Kugyo (top court official) FUJIWARA no Tokihira was the first to be appointed to this post, but in later years it became a concurrent post for the Sadaijin (Minister of the Left).

sen.j: ただし、左大臣が関白であった時は、右大臣が別当となる。
sen.e: However, when Sadaijin served as Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), Udaijin (Minister of the Right) became Kurodo no betto.
When the Sadaijin served as Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), however, the Udaijin (Minister of the Right) became the Kurodo no betto.

sen.j: 例としては室町幕府の征夷大将軍である足利義満が1382年2月9日（弘和2年/永徳2年1月26日）に、左大臣就任の後、3月4日（閏1月19日）、蔵人別当を兼務している。
sen.e: For example, after Seii Taishogun (literally "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was appointed to Sadaijin on February 9, 1382, he held the post of Kurodo no betto concurrently on March 4, 1382.
